observationText: The NPcis mice are a compound heterozygous model with mutations in both the Nf1 and Trp53 genes on a C57BL/6 background, generated by breeding male NPcis mice with wildtype females as homozygous knockouts are embryonically lethal.
The NPcis mice develop malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors (MPNSTs) with high penetrance, mimicking the human disease neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1).
Preneoplastic lesions are consistently observed in NPcis mice by 3 months of age, which progress to symptomatic MPNSTs requiring euthanasia by 7-9 months due to neurological symptoms in 100% of mice.
The NPcis model exhibits allelic imbalance and genetic modifiers on chromosomes 15 and 19 that influence MPNST susceptibility.
The NPcis mice show stunted growth and reduced body weight/size compared to wildtype littermates, with the growth defects stabilizing at around 50% of normal by a few days after birth.

The NPcis mice exhibited allelic imbalance and genetic modifiers on chromosomes 15 and 19 that influenced malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor (MPNST) susceptibility when backcrossed to different strains.
Homozygous Nf1/Trp53 knockout mice are embryonically lethal, so the NPcis model is maintained by breeding heterozygous males with wildtype females.
NPcis mice exhibited a higher incidence of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors (MPNSTs) when inheriting the mutant Nf1 and Trp53 alleles paternally compared to maternally.
